Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Adaptive Representations for NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=151231063; y=ZvVxcL86zQAJTENKewisdOMe3wCjPlH5jn_EjnLsB-geuQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: joeraii

Hey Ken,

We used a very simple version of MaxSolve that keeps an unbounded  
number of teachers around. An organism's fitness is then just  
calculated as the total fitness derived from playing against the  
teachers. When some organism's MaxSolve fitness exceeds the  
previously inserted teacher's MaxSolve fitness, then that organism is  
inserted into the teacher set. This approach implements the same  
solution concept (maximization of expected fitness), but its  
conceptually much simpler than the true MaxSolve algorithm.  
Specifically we don't deal with the case where the teacher set gets  
very large, and thus evaluation time may grow linearly at each  
generation. In practice though, at least for nothello, this never  
turned out to be a problem computationally since we limit ourselves  
to 200 evals.

We actually tried NEAT both with speciation on and off and it didn't  
make a significant difference in the final fitness v. random. I  
suppose you might construe that as evidence of bad interactions with  
fitness sharing, but the coevolutionary version does outperform  
standard NEAT evolved against a random player, so I'm not entirely sure.

-- Joe

On Apr 14, 2007, at 12:00 AM, Kenneth Stanley wrote:

> Joe, how did you program MaxSolve coevolution?  Does that have any
> bad interactions with fitness sharing in NEAT (some methods for
> coevolution do) or is it pretty well compatible?
>
> ken
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@...> wrote:
>>
>> So a few days back I mentioned some adaptive representations work
>> I've been doing using NEAT to study the effects of "development"
> on
>> evolvability. This research has some of the same goals as Ken's
> CPPN
>> work, but the approach is quite different. Using a very simple
>> "indirect" encoding of neural network weights that has some of the
>> features found in GRNs in biology, we show (empirically) that both
>> the final performance and sample complexity of NeuroEvolution can
> be
>> improved in a coevolutionary setting.
>>
>> But the story gets even better: Making random mutations to the
>> champions that result from the GRN-like encoding, we find that
>> performance degrades much more slowly than when the same number of
>> mutations are made to NEAT-encoded networks. Furthermore, if we
> plot
>> this fitness degradation against network distance instead of
> mutation
>> distance, we find that each mutation is having a vastly larger
>> phenotypic effect on the GRN-encoded neural nets. In other words
>> performance is decreasing /less/ even when we make /larger/
> changes
>> to the network topology and weights. This kind of artifact is
> exactly
>> what we'd like to see in so-called "evolvable" encodings: The
>> representation has learned to bias the effects of mutation towards
>> better networks
>>
>> Anyway, this work is definitely still only a first step, but I
> find
>> it very exciting. My paper is even going up against Ken's CPPN
> paper
>> for the best paper award in the GDS track at GECCO. Wish me luck :)
>>
>> If you are at all interested, you should definitely take a look:
>>
>> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?reisinger:gecco07
>>
>> -- Joe
>>
